column5: LAWFUL BASIS FOR SERVICE PROVISION / COMMISSIONING (where applicable)
column6: ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

column3: i. Specialised and highly specialised services
column5: DUTY: To provide services for rare and very rare conditions
column6: NHS England is responsible for commissioning £15.6 billion of specialised services to meet a wide range of health and care needs. These include a range of services from renal dialysis and secure inpatient mental health services, through to treatments for rare cancers and life threatening genetic disorders. The commissioning of specialised services is a prescribed direct commissioning responsibility of NHS England.

column5: DUTY: To provide primary medical services
column6: NHS England is responsible for commissioning primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

column5: DUTY: To exercise relevant public health functions
column6: The NHS has a critical part to play in securing good population health. The public health functions agreement (S7A) is an annual agreement between the Secretary of State for Health and NHS England. These services include services from pregnancy to age 5, immunisations and national screening.

column5: DUTY: To provide health service for prisoners
column6: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 gave the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for persons who are detained in a prison or in other accommodation of a prescribed description. This responsibility also includes commissioning Sexual Assault Referral services.

column5: DUTY: To provide health services to the armed forces
column6: Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, gives the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for members of the Armed Forces or their families.

column5: DUTY: To provide community dental services
column6: NHS England is responsible for commissioning secondary dental services.

column5: DUTY: To provide high secure  psychiatric services
DUTY: To provide primary ophthalmic services
DUTY: To provide pharmaceutical services
DUTY:  To provide mental health after care services
DUTY:  To assess the performance of CCGs
column6: Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) were established on 1 April 2013 and are clinically-led organisations at the heart of the NHS system.

column3: ii. Assurance of major service changes and redesigns
column6: NHS England’s role in reconfiguration is to support commissioners and their local partners to develop clear, evidence based proposals for service reconfiguration, and to undertake assurance as mandated by the Government.

column3: iii. Development of health and care policy and financial allocations
column6: NHS England leads the National Health Service (NHS) in England. It sets the priorities and direction of the NHS and encourage and inform the national debate to improve health and care.

column5: DUTY: Assessment and provisions of NHS continuing healthcare
DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Includes Urgent and emergency care (including 111, A&E and ambulance services) for anyone present in a CCGs geographic area and out-of-hours primary medical services (for everyone present in your area), except where this responsibility has been retained by practices under the GP contract

column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Covers elective hospital care

column5: POWER: To commission certain other health services
column6: Includes speech and language therapy, continence services, wheelchair services, and home oxygen services, but not public health services such as health visiting and family nursing

column3: iv. GP with special interests activity
column5: POWER: To commission certain other health services
column6: Covers other community-based services, including (where appropriate) services provided by GP practices that go beyond the scope of the GP contract

column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Rehabilitation services

column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Excludes neonatal intensive care

column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Covers children's mental and physical health

column5: DUTY:   Co-operation with social services regarding the provision of NHS continuing healthcare
column6: NHS Continuing Healthcare

column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Infertility Services

column3: x. Mental health and learning disabilities
column5: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column6: Includes mental health services, psychological therapies and services for people with learning disabilities

column5: DUTY: Improving quality of primary medical services
column6: CCGs have a responsibility to support systems improvements in local primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

column5: DUTY: Provide services to improve public health
column6: Healthy child programme for school-age children (aged 5-19), including school nursing

column5: DUTY: To provide open access sexual health services
column6: Including contraception over and above GP contract, testing and treatment of sexually transmitted infections (excluding HIV treatment), sexual health advice, prevention and promotion

column5: POWER: To provide preventative services
column6: Including mental health promotion, mental illness prevention and suicide prevention

column3: iv. Physical activity and obesity management
column5: DUTY: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column6: Local programmes to address inactivity and other interventions to promote physical activity, local programmes to prevent and address obesity, e.g. National Child Measurement Programme and weight management services

column5: DUTY: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column6: Drug and alcohol misuse services, prevention and treatment, local tobacco activity, including stop smoking services, prevention activity, enforcement and communications

column5: DUTY:  To provide dental public health services
column6: Including epidemiology, dental screening and oral health improvement, including water fluoridation (subject to consultation)

column3: vii. Other local authority public health services
column5: DUTY: Provide services to improve public health
column6: Including nutrition, NHS Health Check programme, reducing and preventing birth defects, health at work, accidental injury prevention, seasonal mortality, public health and justice, infectious diseases, health protection

column5: DUTY: Provide services to improve public health
column6: Healthy child programme for school-age children (aged 5-19), including school nursing

column5: POWER: To provide preventative services

column2: 3. Providing public health population healthcare advice
column5: DUTY: To co-operate with CCGs and NHS England
column6: Local authorities, as part of their statutory functions around public health, will have responsibility for providing healthcare public health advice to clinical commissioning groups (CCGs)

column3: xi. Specialised and highly specialised services
column6: NHS England is responsible for commissioning £15.6 billion of specialised services to meet a wide range of health and care needs. These include a range of services from renal dialysis and secure inpatient mental health services, through to treatments for rare cancers and life threatening genetic disorders. The commissioning of specialised services is a prescribed direct commissioning responsibility of NHS England.
NHS England is responsible for commissioning primary care services, including primary medical care, pharmaceutical services, ophthalmic services and dental services.

The NHS has a critical part to play in securing good population health. The public health functions agreement (S7A) is an annual agreement between the Secretary of State for Health and NHS England. These services include services from pregnancy to age 5, immunisations and national screening.

Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 gave the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for persons who are detained in a prison or in other accommodation of a prescribed description. This responsibility also includes commissioning Sexual Assault Referral services.

Section 15 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, gives the Secretary of State the power to require NHS England to commission services or facilities for members of the Armed Forces or their families.
NHS England is responsible for commissioning secondary dental services.
